short_description: The quintessential Algerian dish featuring fluffy steamed semolina topped with a rich vegetable stew and various meats. This Friday tradition brings families together around a communal platter.
steps: In a couscoussier or steamer, brown lamb and chicken in oil.
Add sliced onions and cook until softened.
Add tomatoes, ras el hanout, salt, and water to cover.
Bring to boil, add soaked chickpeas, reduce to simmer.
Meanwhile, moisten couscous with salted water and let rest.
Steam couscous over the stew for 20 minutes.
Fluff couscous, add butter, steam again for 20 minutes.
Add harder vegetables (carrots, turnips) to stew.
After 30 minutes, add softer vegetables (zucchini).
Grill merguez separately, slice when cooked.
Serve couscous on large platter, arrange meat and vegetables on top.
cooking_tips: The couscous must be steamed, not boiled, for proper fluffiness.
Break up any lumps in the couscous between steamings.
The broth should be ladled over when serving.
nutrition_benefits: A complete meal with protein from multiple meat sources. Chickpeas add plant protein and fiber. The variety of vegetables provides vitamins and minerals.

short_description: A hearty Algerian dish from the Aurès region featuring torn flatbread pieces soaked in a spiced meat and vegetable stew. This rustic comfort food is packed with flavor.
steps: Make a simple flatbread dough with semolina, salt, and water.
Knead until smooth, rest for 30 minutes.
Roll thin and cook on a dry griddle until done but not crispy.
Tear the bread into small pieces and set aside.
Brown lamb in oil, add onions and garlic.
Add tomatoes, harissa, cumin, and water.
Simmer until lamb is tender, about 1 hour.
Add cooked chickpeas in the last 15 minutes.
Place torn bread in serving dishes.
Ladle hot stew over bread, let soak briefly before serving.
cooking_tips: The bread should be soft enough to absorb the sauce.
Don't let the bread get too soggy - serve immediately.
Adjust harissa to your spice preference.
nutrition_benefits: Lamb provides iron and B12. Chickpeas add fiber and plant protein. Tomatoes offer lycopene and vitamin C.

short_description: Algerian-style stuffed vegetables featuring a medley of zucchini, peppers, and tomatoes filled with spiced meat and rice, simmered in a savory tomato sauce.
steps: Hollow out zucchini and peppers, saving the flesh.
Scoop out tomatoes, chop the flesh.
Mix ground beef with rice, chopped onion, parsley, and spices.
Stuff vegetables loosely with meat mixture.
Arrange stuffed vegetables in a deep pot.
Mix tomato paste with water and chopped tomato flesh.
Pour sauce around the vegetables.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 1 hour.
Check occasionally, adding water if needed.
Serve hot with crusty bread to soak up the sauce.
cooking_tips: Don't pack the filling too tight - rice needs room to expand.
The vegetables should be snug in the pot to prevent tipping.
A splash of lemon juice at the end brightens the flavors.
nutrition_benefits: A vegetable-rich dish providing vitamins A and C from peppers and tomatoes. The balanced combination of protein, carbs, and vegetables makes it nutritionally complete.

short_description: A beloved Algerian soup made with freekeh (roasted green wheat), lamb, and a bounty of vegetables. This hearty soup is essential during Ramadan for breaking the fast.
steps: Rinse freekeh well and soak for 30 minutes.
Cut lamb into small pieces, brown in olive oil.
Add diced onions and cook until soft.
Add tomato paste and grated tomatoes.
Pour in 3 liters of water, add chickpeas and ras el hanout.
Simmer for 45 minutes until lamb is tender.
Add drained freekeh and continue cooking for 30 minutes.
Add chopped celery and cilantro.
Season with salt and lemon juice.
Serve hot with crusty bread and lemon wedges.
cooking_tips: Freekeh has a unique smoky flavor that defines this soup.
The soup thickens as it sits - add more broth when reheating.
Fresh mint can be added as a garnish.
nutrition_benefits: Freekeh is a superfood grain high in fiber and protein. The soup is hydrating and nutritious, perfect for breaking a fast. Rich in vitamins from fresh herbs and vegetables.

short_description: Traditional Algerian semolina cookies stuffed with sweet date paste, fried until golden, and dipped in honey syrup. These diamond-shaped treats are beloved during celebrations.
steps: Mix semolina with melted butter, oil, salt, and orange blossom water.
Add water gradually to form a soft, pliable dough.
Let rest for 30 minutes.
Mix date paste with cinnamon until smooth.
Divide dough into portions and roll into long cylinders.
Flatten each, place date paste in center, fold and seal.
Roll gently to even thickness.
Cut into diamond shapes at an angle.
Deep fry in batches until golden brown.
Immediately dip in warm honey, let excess drip off.
Cool on a rack and serve at room temperature.
cooking_tips: The dough should be soft but not sticky.
Don't overcrowd the fryer - they expand slightly.
Warm the honey for easier coating.
nutrition_benefits: Dates are high in fiber and natural sugars for quick energy. Semolina provides complex carbohydrates. Honey has natural antibacterial properties.
